review_title: Great Place to Work, Horrible HR
pros: Enjoyed working with my colleagues while there and were able to get a lot done in our respective assignment.

pros: Potential for interesting work, involved in sciences, large campus could in theory lead to other opportunities. Johns Hopkins looks good on resume. Good benefits and retirement plan. Allowed work from home/hybrid during covid, but that benefit is mostly over.
cons: Illegal forced overtime for non-exempt employees. Some employees with connections do little and collect a paycheck, others without connections are treated as disposable work horses. Outdated softwares which makes work more difficult than need be. Most employees are passive aggressive and just out for themselves, which makes cooperative tasks more difficult. Long -term staff employees seem over-medicated or in a daze and sadly, they begin counting years to retirement when they are barely 40 and have many years to go. Pay is not competitive, and JHU fully expects a 2yr revolving door for many employees; little or no effort to retain. In fact, they rather you leave so they can get fresh faces and pay them a pittance until they, in turn, leave. This is why JHU has such an entrenched reputation as a place to get on your resume and leave; it is very difficult to stay with rising living costs and virtually no raises, or a tiny token raise. JHU pretends to be broke when dealing with rank and file employees, though the money flows like a river to managers and pet projects. Parking is a nightmare if you do not have a special faculty parking spot, and expensive too, even through JHU parking office.

cons: Working on the East Baltimore campus brings even more cons: a violent neighborhood, constant construction/development with road closures, and expensive employee parking. JHU underpays everyone: Staff and faculty for sure, but ESPECIALLY their adjunct faculty and grad workers. The Office of Institutional Equity is in place to make the university keep a "clean" look despite numerous negative reports filed by students, staff, and postdocs. Zero career growth opportunities. Too many cons to list...

review_title: An excellent university with a debatable president
pros: Overall attractive work environment and career opportunities.
cons:
1) The president Ron Daniels' leadership style is under debate. Ron resorted to police force to help resolve conflict with student protesters, made his own decision over academic council in deciding faculty tenure and suspended retirement benefits and salary increase for all staff and faculty during the covid pendamic. However, Ron is still the university president who earns multiple times of the income as the presidents of Harvard and MIT.

2) There is an age bias in the current Johns Hopkins retirement benefit policies - If you were hired as a faculty when you were younger than 35 years old, you have to work with ZERO employer retirement contribution in the first two years, then half employer retirement contribution compared to older peers. So you are doing the same work but are punished for being young! This biased term is rarely found in other private and public universities.

review_title: Not a great place for postdoc
pros: Good research topics and funding options, just like any other R01 institute.
cons:
Lack of support for postdocs:
1. You will never get proper mentorship from anyone because everyone is very busy, especially PIs. 
2. Be ready to experience discrimination. Even though they talk a lot about equity, diversity, etc. They do not take satisfactory action to address those issues. If you are a woman of color or an international postdoc, you might experience discrimination or bias because Hopkins has those big-name Profs who are not very concerned about equity or mentorship in general. 
3. You will be paying a lot of money to insurance if you have a dependent, like a lot (please do your research)... And even if you have Hopkins insurance (EHP), a doctor's office visit will cost 400$ in the hospital...
4. Toxic research environment. No support and onboarding process and high expectations from postdocs. If you underdeliver for some reason, you get threats about being fired. 
5. A lot of politics...
6. There is a lot of competition between postdocs, PhDs because of the toxic environment.

review_title: I would not recommend working at John’s Hopkins Center for Talented Youth.
pros: The best reasons to work here are the larger umbrella of Hopkins and the benefits associated with it. The employees (other than leadership) are amazing.
cons: This is truly one of the worst places I have ever worked, due to lack of true leadership, not treating employees with respect, leaders who prioritize lifting themselves up while putting down their own team members and other teams, and inequitable treatment of women and minorities. Salaries are low, morale is low, turnover is high. Management is top down: they don’t want to hear what is really happening or what the people doing the work have to say. They don’t trust their own team members, and regularly hire external consultants to do work that their teams have the skill set to do. People are treated like pure resources rather than human beings, and there is no sense of team in the work we do. Expectations change constantly, and leadership often promises one thing but does another.

This is for the SAIS school in DC, although I interacted with the Central JHU in Baltimore alot as well. Every department operated like its own silo, with its own resources and budget. Everything was reactive and a quick fix, versus building up from the ground up.
Bad at hiring corporate/staff roles. Can't speak for academia roles.

review_title: (DAR) Incredible organization with lots of opportunities, lackluster management
pros:
Tons of opportunities in the development and alumni relations office, possible to transition into other roles across the Hopkins system
Lots of people are lifers because it's such a stimulating and impactful organization. Some truly wonderful colleagues.
Lots of autonomy.
Interesting external community with truly unique characteristics, partly due to bias toward graduate education and practical research
Considered to be a leader in development and alumni relations - the Hopkins name is valuable on a resume
Genuine and increasing commitment to diversity
cons:
Cutthroat in certain parts of the organization
Poor commitment to values (bad behavior is often swept under the rug) - organization tends to prop up numbers at the expense of people, and the metrics and methods behind them are obsolete in a very demotivating way 
Frustrating management - general lack of basic management training and best practices, though organization is trying to address; culture from top down of fire-fighting instead of taking strategic and innovative risks
Organization dramatically underpays (peers earn 30-45% more for same positions), rationalizing by saying that the relatively low cost of living in Baltimore justifies it and that organization pays "industry average." It's not true, and everyone seems to know it. People stay because they generally like Hopkins or think it's a good career move.

review_title: The overall experience at the University has been satisfactory; however, there have been bumps in the road.
job_title: PhD Student (Life Sciences) in Baltimore, MD
pros: The academic environment is rich in knowledge and resources. Despite common opinion, Baltimore can be a comfortable (safe and affordable) city to pursue graduate work. The phd student stipend is similar to other graduate programs. However, since Baltimore is an affordable city, the stipend goes far compared to similar programs in NYC, Philadelphia, San Francisco, LA, etc.
cons:
Everywhere you go, you can find bad apples in the bunch. There are some professors (and students) who are full of themselves and are not always a pleasure to work with.

As a black graduate student, the experience has been isolating and there is not much of an administrative effort to address minority student issues. In addition, there are very little protections in place for graduate students/post-docs abused by their "advisors" (including advisors who yell at and bully their students into submission, foreign students/post-docs (and possibly Americans) working 100+ hr weeks from demanding professors who pay them less than NIH guidelines or nothing).


Finally, the University is politically and administratively segregated into various schools. This separation makes students (and possibly faculty) feel very confined within their own school and limits the ability to collaborate and connect outside of one's school. This separation leads to very different experiences depending on where you are in the University or School. Even within a Department, students can have very different experiences depending on which lab you choose to join.

review_title: CCP is a great place to work
pros:
As a younger employee, there have been so many opportunities ranging from international travel to developing new technical skills. I feel that this is an organization that I can grow into. There are a lot of older employees that have been here for 15-20+ years, but they are hiring a lot younger staff, and they recognize the need to involve youth in their fantastic work. I really appreciate that about CCP. This is the type of place where you feel like what you do makes a positive difference in this world.

CCP is filled with energizing and intelligent people (from all over the world) who you can go to for any questions or advice. Even the director keeps her door open. I've made a lot of friends here - it's nice to work at a place where you can grab a coffee or have lunch with people you like! I know that not everyone loves their jobs, so I feel lucky to be a part of such a wonderful organization.
cons: A lot of people here work overtime. Sometimes you have to work outside of your regular hours to get things done, but are there any jobs that aren't like that? Work-life balance is a big topic here, and a lot of people are working hard to improve it - including senior management staff. I've heard that some people have been unhappy here and left to work somewhere else. There are also a lot of people that leave and come back.

pros: Pretty standard financial analyst work, not rocket science. Great benefits. Awesome organization to have on my resume; Johns Hopkins is recognized all over the world.
cons: Hired by a manager that I loved and looked up to. Fair, understanding, helpful, etc.. After she left there was no one to fill her spot and so someone else on our team (unqualified) was put into her role. No idea what he was doing. Frustrating to work for, spoke in circles, not helpful when I had questions or needed help with my work. Attitude was "Keep working on it, I'm sure you'll figure it out yourself!" Underappreciated. Management pretends to care but they don't. I stuck it out as long as I could under this new guy but threw in the towel and quit. Looking back, I wish that I had taken the time to look elsewhere within the organization for a new position/role. But at the time, I was certain that it would be the same no matter what location/department I worked for, within the organization. Recently (2 years later) I applied and interviewed for another Financial Analyst role within Johns Hopkins University (completely different location/department) and was pleasantly surprised at what a positive impression I have. Hoping that the negative experience 2 years ago was just within that team/department/location, I guess we'll see. (PS - JHU pays low, you have to decide for yourself if the benefits make up for it or not)

job_title: Research Program Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: Good benefits, HR department is easy to work with, diverse top-level research projects, wonderful mentors, lots of networking opportunities, numerous opportunities for other projects if you want to try something else
cons:
Research teams get clique-y and possessive, especially if you are split between projects. When you are meant to be 50/50 effort, it never works out that way.

Very female-oriented leaving the (very) qualified male coworkers without much support (females hired and promoted over males with more experience). I encountered more than one woman in management positions who saw the males as "eye candy" for their team rather than brains and a good, efficient, hard-working team member.

Hopkins has gone overboard on the diversity to the point at which the workplace is no longer diverse. Offices are practically 80% female, primarily Asian and black, which a large percentage being international rather than domestic. It makes domestic workers feel ostracized when half their team speaks Chinese and ignore the rest of the team to gossip and hang out during work hours. No one can even call them out because they can't understand them.

pros: Administrative staff is given a very high level of responsibility. There is room to grow because your skill set will expand quickly. Having Hopkins on your resume opens many, many doors.  There is a culture of excellence there that demands respect from others. Great benefits, lots of training classes for professional development purposes. The library is first class, tremendous resources.  Lots of free food all the time because of so many campus events.
cons: Everyone there is majorly stressed out. Pay is not competitive, especially with UMB, UMBC and UMCP nearby. The work never seems to stop, it's a 24/7 type of thing where you are seen as less committed if you only work during business hours.  Completely normal to see a lower level admin responding to emails at 10pm on a Friday night. Other than the lifers (those who are grandfathered under the old pension plan), most sane people will eventually burn out and leave. Although some people thrive here, the university is definitely not for everyone. This is also the type of institution which will fire you in a heartbeat. There is no job security so it's best to leave when the crazy starts to show.

That's because there are like six or seven right hands at each campus and they never talk. The internal business model is atrocious, with departments charging one another for goods/services that should be simply included in a general operational budget. The bloated administrative arm takes a big cut from all grants, with little support given to those who bring them in. To that end, most tenured professors would rather be conducting their research than teach, resulting in a student-hostile climate.

pros: The Johns Hopkins Institution has been my home for many years. I have been with them since the concept of wireless network deployments the institutions values are very important to me. I feel as if I am to better gauge my understandings of the field I will have to regrettably move on and find career advancement and hopefully provide the same level of service at another establishment in a technology that changes rapidly.

review_title: Hot research but not a meritocracy
pros:
JHU SoM has a fantastic scientific environment that not only fosters "bleeding edge" multidisciplinary science but encourages collaborations within and without the university. Every kind of equipment is there and available through cores or collaboration. Patenting in also strongly encouraged and enabled by the Tech Transfer office.

Benefits for faculty are excellent and include health, life, dental, disability, tuition remission (50%) if your kid gets accepted to a college within Maryland and a 403(b) plan.
cons:
Not a meritocracy at all in terms of promotion or salary. No transparency for either.

M.D. "faculty" are treated entirely differently from Ph.D. faculty despite sharing the same rank in the same department. This really lowers morale.

Salaries are very low (25th percentile in my field).

Baltimore is not a nice place despite low cost of living. I and several of my colleagues have been robbed, one beaten severely, one killed by stab wounds.

For those with K-12 age kids, public schools in the city are tough. Parents either live in burb and commute every day or perhaps people with $$$ pay private school tuition.

review_title: Good place to start in academia
pros:
-Good environment for learning a lot in research, especially good if you are looking to pursue a career in academia.
-Awesome benefits in medical insurance, the lowest I've ever paid for full coverage.
-Free public transportation to work! As long as you live in the Baltimore City area, they have shuttles that will take you to work for free between their 4 campuses.
cons:
-JHU lowballs salary EXCESSIVELY, it doesn't matter if you have a high degree under your belt. Ivy league knows you'll bite the bullet for a lower salary just to have their name on your resume.
-Some benefits don't start until 2 year anniversary, it is my thought they have this in effect because of a high turnover rate. People stay for 1-2 years, get the experience and the name, and then depart.
-No growth. Management has neat squares for their employees to stay in, they don't push for professional development within the university.
-Poor culture. I moved to Baltimore not knowing anyone. I was surprised there was no groups for employee involvement (being such a HUGE presence in Baltimore). My first year was very lonely and working in a small lab made it very hard to meet new people. This affected my work-life balance and motivation to do my job.

review_title: After 4 months, it is still better than I could have hoped for!
pros: The benefits. There are too many to name, but Hopkins is obviously trying to keep up with the work/life balance issue by making sure that we get the best opportunities. The staff is kind and sincere about helping someone new become comfortable. The university as a whole is run in a organized fashion with very few hiccups. If you pull your own weight, expect to enjoy your job. If you are not a self starter, this is not the place for you. At least in my department, everyone works hard including the management but we all go home on time, and not stressed about the piles of work on our desk.
cons: The neighborhood. Unfortunately this is true for most employers in the city, and we do have security on every corner, and security guards to walk you to your car at night. But there is no denying that this is not the safest area to be, especially after dark. Parking is also a huge con, as it can sometimes take 25 minutes just to get from the campus to my car parked at the satellite lot.

job_title: Patient Access Specialist in Baltimore, MD
pros: Work from home and benefits
cons: Hard to move up and mundane

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Baltimore, MD
pros: The largest advantage to a bio PhD at Hopkins over other graduate schools is the world-class hospital operating in the same complex. Collaboration between medical and research is easy to come by, as well as is access to patients and patient samples (following proper protocols, of course).
cons: Hopkins has invested less in modernizing the graduate student experience than other graduate schools. Receiving a PhD is still fundamentally a medieval apprenticeship, with one mentor responsible for your entire livelihood and future - time until graduation, research opportunities, ability to attend national meetings, conferences, etc. While other graduate schools have modified the experience to put more autonomy in the hands of students, Hopkins has not.

review_title: A world-class university with some distinctly mediocre systems. Nevertheless, it's a great place to work.
pros: Great benefits, and a real openness to flexible work schedules -- a tremendous plus. Lots of learning opportunities (personally and professionally). There are many wonderful classes you can take for free or nearly free. Good retirement benefits. Job stability (as compared to the private sector, unless you're in a grant-funded unit).  A commitment to diversity (although by no means a perfect execution). Hopkins has a lot of "lifers", and there are some very good reasons why.
cons: Most administrative functions (like IT) are shockingly mediocre.  How happy you are will be directly related to how good your individual manager/unit leader is.  There are continuous culture wars between faculty and staff, between senior staff and support staff, between Medicine and University. Strangely overzealous Security who spend their time policing the Hopkins population rather than keeping us safe from the outside world.

job_title: Research Program Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros:
- Famous, advanced institution
- good benefits (insurances, tuition remission and other)
- wide knowledge based
- some good PIs interested in not only their career but also in your development
- good coworkers if you are lucky to have them
cons:
- very stingy in case of salaries and raise, all the money goes for construction of new flashy buildings
- many supervisors have habit of micromanaging and putting you to work for every millisecond during your work hours  to the point of harassment and disgust, which is discouraging
- administrative, payroll and HR department do not listen to your problems and are most of the time uninformed and not willing to help. 
- people play politics to go ahead with their ambitions
- efforts are not only go unrewarded but also go unacknowledged
- no flexible hours, had to seat through 9 to 5 sharp everyday regardless of work load

pros: Love working with the JHU community and feel very lucky to be a part of it! The hours are great (37.5 per week); am non-exempt (get overtime) and travel occasionally. Tuition reimbursement is a great perk! Lots of opportunities to move to difference departments within the Hopkins system and typically they like to hire/promote from within. Lots of perk programs to save money, housing help, and discounts! Your day-to-day experience will differ greatly based on who you support, which school and departments you are affiliated with!
cons: Hopkins benefits are great if you are married and have school age children. If you are not married or married without children the benefits (tuition) don't have any impact. Parking can be an issue depending on which campus you commute to. Hopkins, like the federal government does not offer maternity/paternity leave - it is only Short Term and Long Term disability (plus sick/vacation leave).

review_title: Johns Hopkins is a good place to make a difference
pros: There are a variety of opportunities within the university system. At APL, they offer a wide spectrum of industry work for the US government. Their goal is to make critical contributions to the nation, so the work is typically on the leading edge of the applied sciences.
cons: At APL, there is a strong push to be relevant but practical when it comes to solutions. The risks taken must be balanced with the ability to make an impact in the short term. The most notable issue is their deep reliance and strong interest in classical systems engineering and linear innovation paths.

review_title: Take the opportunity to learn and be prepared to move on...
pros: The institution itself is phenomenal and you have the opportunity to interact and collaborate with some really brilliant people. If you take initiative, you are given the opportunity to learn and work fairly independently. The prestige of the institution is widely recognized.
cons: Hopkins often feels too large and incredibly decentralized. If you decide, as an employee/new hire, to work hard and take on new tasks and challenges, you should be prepared to not see any increase in title/pay. Hopkins often allows good employees to take on more and more responsibility without appropriately acknowledging them. When it is a busy time of year, things are absolutely chaotic. The institution, specifically leadership, is very traditional and youth is discreted in the sense that colleagues can be very condescending to younger employees.

review_title: Steady, stable job, with good benefits and decent work -- personnel a little unfriendly in a big impersonal setting
pros: I like the stability. If the economy implodes, this place will still have jobs and money flowing through it. Lots of opportunity to move around if you don't like the department you are in. Benefits are great, and the people are fine to work with for the most part.
cons: Politics. You rarely move up unless you know someone. Even when you work hard you get a measly 2% raise and a pat on the head. The people can be very unfriendly -- especially at the upper levels and if you are a minority. Parking costs way too much and is too far (hospital/med campus only -- Homewood is decent).

review_title: Smart hardworking company but low salaries
job_title: Senior Professional Staff I in Baltimore, MD
pros:
Staff and students are very smart and work very hard to do outstanding work
If you have college age children the benefits for tuition remission are excellent
Great people come to work here because of the reputation of excellence, but salaries mean you are just starting in the field or need a spouse to subsidize your career choice
cons:
If you plan to have a child or have a child under 18, there are few benefits, no maternity or paternity leave and no daycare available.
Salaries stagnated in 2005 and have raises have remained lower than rate of inflation since 2008
Very hard to keep good staff because of low salaries
In the past 3-4 years most upper administration has been removed or left for other institution which creates an environment of uncertainty for the future
Have reduced benefits available to new employees.

pros: As with all large organizations, your expereince at JHU will depend a great deal on the department in which you work. Pros included co-workers who are genuinely focused on the public health mission of Johns Hopkins and passionate about providing the best possible services, whether directly related to patient care or more peripherally impacting patient care. There's a lot of exciting, really good work going on at Hopkins.
cons:
My particular department (which is not directly involved in patient care) is a cesspool of politics. Leadership is tremendously insecure and shuts down concerns pretty quickly because that's a challenge to authority. There's an attitude that because we're Hopkins we can just "wing it" on quite a few things and get away with it. The quality of work can be mediocre to poor as a consequence.  

Salary is not at all competitive.

review_title: Great place to work as a postdoc
pros: As a postdoc you have extremely flexible work hours, the position is really results based rather than time based.  You'll get the opportunity to work on cutting edge scientific research in your field.  There is a postdoc association that has significantly improved the quality of life for postdocs over the past ten years, giving us benefits such as free access to the gym.
cons: The pay is lower than an industry position,  but generous compared to other university postdoc programs. As at every major academic institution, there is a large amount of bureaucracy to deal with. Additionally, working on the main campus it seemed that there was less interdepartmental collaboration than at other academic institutions where I have worked.

job_title: On-Campus Student Consultant in Baltimore, MD
pros: I am always provided with to-the-point instructions concerning my job as a study consultant for my fellow undergraduate friends. The pay is very well for the amount of work required. My boss is open to discussion as to how to improve the on-campus job environment, and management.
cons: The job requires you to be very accurate about your timing, which is difficult as a student who works part-time on-campus. When you schedule you appointments with your students, you have to be certain that the student is able to attend, otherwise the absence procedure is very cumbersome.

review_title: Big name, good benefits, low pay
pros: Hopkins offers you the title of having a big name school in your resume, particularly useful for research positions. It also offers you great benefits, such as great health insurance (Hopkins med) and tuition reimbursement at a top tiers school if you decide to take classes while working full time. Finally, the best part about my job in particular, is that as long as I can get my work done within a timely manner, I get to leave early (this was established beforehand with my boss). On average I work about 20-30 hours a week but receive a 40-hour work week salary.
cons: The pay seems to be under average, though this may depend highly on which department you work in. Generally in research your salary is highly dependent on how much grant funding your PI has.

review_title: Benefits Don't Always Outweigh the Costs
pros: Great benefits which grow over time, flexible work environment (depending on your supervisor/division), tuition benefit if you want to take Hopkins classes, lots of opportunities for training and tooling up
cons: Stagnant org chart/hierarchy, not a lot of paths for upward mobility/professional growth in staff roles, HR policies aren't applied consistently across the board and can create tension or a hostile environment over perceived inequity, not a lot of transparency between faculty, administration, and staff regarding decision-making, and high turnover of Dean's office leads to constant leadership changes and no long term strategy being implemented

review_title: The reputation of the institution is only the tip of the iceberg
pros: As a simple summer intern, I learned more in two months than all the Lab classes I've taken to date. They treat you like a grad student. You can take this as a gift, run with it, and learn crazy amounts of extremely useful skills. Best lab experience of my life, I was assigned a mentor who gave me literature to read (took his time to find articles that would be useful) and made sure I understood why I was doing whatever it was that I was doing (western blot, qPCR, etc..) and how these assays functioned.
cons: You will be working with some of the best and brightest, people at the top of their fields and brilliant graduate students. It's easy to become a bit intimidated. Also, housing wasn't paid for.

review_title: APL is a good place to work if you want something stable and consistent but with mediocre salaries
job_title: Senior Professional Staff I in Laurel, MD
pros: APL is a very stable organization with a very laid-back atmosphere.  The retirement benefits are very good (403b), one can take off for vacation with little notice, 3+ weeks of vacation per year,  flexible hours and tele-commuting possible.
cons: It is a very bipolar place - either you are a technical worker and not recognized or you are in management and run with the big boys.  Only realistic way to move up is to go into management.  Unfortunately a lot of the people in management should not be there as they are not very good at it.  Salary is only so-so.  Raises at end of year rarely meet inflation.

review_title: A great place to do research
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Baltimore, MD
pros: Contact with some of the biggest names in the field of Biophysics.  As long as you do good work, vacations and days off are really up to you.  In all physical science departments, funding is not an issue.  Most PIs are very good at obtaining grants and pointing students to fellowships.  If you want to do research in Biology, Biophysics or Chemistry, this is a place to do it.  Great crystallography and NMR facilities.  Lots of collaborations with national and international laboratories.
cons: No dental.  They seem to hire faculty exclusively from the outside.  So there if you are a postdoc at Hopkins, you will probably not get to be a faculty at Hopkins without going to work outside first.  Very little connection with the industry.  Everyone except for the faculty gets treated as a student.

review_title: Tough on the ego unless you are among the elite leadership
job_title: Senior Research Program Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: Meaningful work; you can be immersed in a scientific environment that matters, and if you are good at what you do, it's a stable situation.  If you like quiet, solitude, and rarified air, this is the place for you.
cons: Joyless, humorless, where you are on your own; except for rare individuals, or perhaps your office-mate, day-to-day culture is not especially friendly or generous. Academic researchers seem to have completely escaped management training.  If you enjoy collaboration, mentoring and support on both sides (giving and getting), or if you have previously experienced management (such as in the private sector) that really cares about developing others' potential, this will be frustrating.

review_title: Good collegial environment for research and medicine; management often lacks business experience outside academia.
job_title: Senior Quality & Innovation Coach in Baltimore, MD
pros: World-class research and practice for medicine and public health.  There is no shortage of improvement projects to work on.  Lots of pull for Lean Sigma assistance from many parts of the organization.  Lean Sigma colleagues are a great team to work with.  Internal customers are very appreciative of assistance.
cons: Politics trump process innovation.  Change is often squashed by those comfortable with their tenure in the academic side or their longevity growing up in the hospital side.

review_title: JHU -- A pretty decent place to work
pros: Good benefits (but not as good as state schools), especially if you have college age kids.  Pay is ok, nothing that will wow your friends.  However, factoring in benefits, pay, and other perks (decent amounts of time off, flexible schedule) as well as being an accessible "name brand" place to work makes JHU a pretty decent employer.
cons: Pay increases are capped at 3%.  You can't get more than a 5% bump moving jobs.  You can't skip two pay grades.  It's hard to get into management if you are less than 40 years old.  Things move pretty slowly.

job_title: Unix Administrator III in Baltimore, MD
pros:
The benefits and PTO would be the best reasons to work at Johns Hopkins, as would the relatively generous educational benefits. As a senior staff employee, you enjoy nearly a combined 2 months PTO per year (12 sick days + 22 vacation + holidays), and after two years you receive 6% directly into your 403b account with TIAA-CREF. 
If you're looking for steady, long-term employment where advancement isn't necessarily your goal (non-faculty speaking, here), then Hopkins is an excellent place to work.
cons: Working directly for a department severely limits one's advancement potential, career-wise. There is a lot of emphasis placed on time served, rather than a job well done. For faculty positions, this obviously isn't a problem. However, for staff positions, this is a severe detriment to keeping quality people around. The pay could be bumped a bit, as well, as the cost of living continues to rise in the Baltimore area.

review_title: JHU is a fine place to begin a career in higher education.
pros: The brand name is a helpful addition to a resume.  Tuition remission, though modest, can offset the cost of furthering one's education.  Tuition refund, for the children of full-time staff and faculty, is worth 50% of annual tuition for undergraduate study at any institution.
cons: The institution is lacking in business process management and data governance.  Every org unit is siloed, and it is difficult to accomplish much on an enterprise scale.  Employee turnover is high.

review_title: If hired, you will not advance if you are not white, no matter you abilities, skills or education.
pros: Benefits and perks are the same as for those at the rest of the university and that's pretty good.
cons: Although not hostile, if you are not in a clique, you're never sure where you stand in the organization and are likely not to receive promotions.  Pay is below average for technology professionals in this area - benefits help may balance the difference.

job_title: Game Theory Instructor in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: There were a lot of really excited and talented kids and faculty at the summer camp (Center for Talented Youth or CTY). You had the opportunity to teach a lot of fun stuff that wouldn't normally be taught. You also got to travel and have fun on weekends if you were wise with your time. A good summer gig!
cons: The program seemed sort of disorganized. For example, two inexperience TA/instructors were paired together and while the experienced ones teaching the same class were paired together. The job is also very exhausting and tiring for a first time instructor.

pros: Has a lot of good equipment and latest technology. They have loads of funds. History has a lot of great people.
cons: Present has no great establishments nor any great achievers like in the past. They have no regulations in place from animal vivarium for research to research ethics. I have seen some bend the rules and claim they are hopkins. Govt has not seemed to notice it with Hopkins. Micromanagement can actually make one commit suicide. I felt immense pressure from day 1. They don’t provide appropriate training and expect you to perform like a pro. There’s constant stalking as to where you are and what you are up to. Wonder how on earth the biggies have ignored these and the university doesn’t follow laws and discipline. It’s unfortunate it has been ranked at no.10 and hospital no.3. Wish someone noticed it to improve. No one likes working here. Occupational health is equally bad in treating new folks.

pros:
Major research power, tons of research-related resources
Incredible opportunities to collaborate with some of the top names in various fields
Some very supportive people
Opportunities to learn the most advanced science in courses that are generally pretty damn good
cons:
PUBLISH OR PERISH
You could get matched with a terrible mentor
Ultra competitive environment
Hard to reach faculty sometimes; mentorship varies a lot
Not a lot of support in developing teaching skills
East Baltimore campus embedded in a crime-ridden area that goes through spurts of regular muggings

review_title: A wonderful place to work...if you are in the right department.
job_title: Academic Program Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: Brilliant people, lots of interdisciplinary energy. Pretty good benefits. It is very decentralized, so if you are in the right department, working with the right faculty/staff it can be a fantastic experience.
cons: The wages are not great, especially for staff, and raises have been small for the last several years, with no signs of getting better. The work climate is department specific, so if you land in a dysfunctional department (and there are a lot of them) then it can be a terrible experience, with micromanaging just the beginning of the list. The decentralized workplace also means that policies and procedures are not usually obvious or set in stone, making much of the work day about diplomacy and figuring out how to make things work (in my case) for the students, instead of just doing the job.

job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros:
Extremely generous vacation, sick, and floating holiday leave program.
Flexible schedules and work from home privileges in many (not all) departments.
JHU is a world-wide leader in research and teaching. Important, exciting work is done here. Proud to be a part of it.
AMAZING benefits for when your children go to college. (50% of tuition paid by JHU.)
cons:
Compensation system is not doing a good enough job of keeping up with long-term employees who learn and grown in their roles here. Advocating for yourself, or moving around to other roles or other departments helps. 

Tuition benefit for employees who are earning a graduate degree is not flexible enough. The tuition remission limit does not go very far given the high cost of tuition at Hopkins. Hopkins doesn't offer all of the programs people might be interested in. It would be better if we could have tuition reimbursement and choose where we want to study.

pros: Prestigious university, get to work with leading researchers, mutiple campuses
cons:
Outdated titles and hiring procedures. The title "Research Service Analyst" is equivalent to "Grant and Contract Analyst". Unfortunately since title is outdated, other universities are not familiar with this job. Addiitonally, pay is lower than surrounding universities. With relation to this title, it is because there is no equitable title although work is similar and it affects market research and equity with nearby universities. Overall, alot of people feel "You work at Hopkins for the reputation, not the pay"

The university is also obsessed with promoting and hiring strictly based on years experience instead of skill-set, which unfortuantely leads to alot of older employees who are stagnant and comfortable without required skill sets.

review_title: Great entry level position for a TRULY SELF-motivated individual
job_title: Academic Program Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: You have your own office on a beautiful college campus. The work environment is relaxed and you'll enjoy good benefits, a gym, a pool, and squash, racquetball & basketball courts just a short walk from your office.
cons: Busy times are REAL busy. Not so busy times are REALLY not busy. Regular work schedule during summer when campus is empty. Days can get monotonous in an office by yourself. If your predecessor doesn't leave you with a step by-step guide to how different procedures, you will be forced to rely on the help of your very busy colleagues in a similar position. This is because your manager is a faculty member/researcher and does not

review_title: If you are thinking of quitting, do yourself a favor and do it now.
job_title: Senior Research Program Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: The salary and benefits are solid and I always had a nice workspace. I worked with a team of wonderful researchers from around the world (in other research institutions, notably) and enjoyed that aspect very much. Some of my colleagues at Hopkins were delightful.
cons: I had no horizontal colleagues at all, only what felt like a bunch of bosses. Some management personnel are exceedingly rude. I got 0 feedback, positive or negative (good to excellent annual reviews on paper, but that was it and they were effectively meaningless). Worked hard and was absolutely, 100%, unappreciated. Actively discouraged from speaking up. Extremely overburdened with duties. No upward mobility whatsoever. Questionable research ethics and quality. Note this was at the SPH--I interned in SOM for a year and it was nothing like this.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: The students are very hard-working individuals, the faculty is top-notch, and TAs are given a lot of freedom regarding the development of curricula.
cons: Everyone is pretty stressed, trying to put out papers, publications, get ready for exams, all while providing superior teaching and prompt grading. The administration seems to get even more bloated every year. The new student union center they're building ensures that Hopkins, too, will go the way of the pay-to-play American education system, catering to the wallets of wealthy undergrads & the parents instead of betting on their ability to deliver a superior educational experience.  American higher education is sales- fine- but who is going to sell us an education? Is it the universities' fault, or is it the parents, who regard a diploma as a status symbol rather than a badge of merit?

review_title: JHU is an awesome environment to find work fullfillment and life balance.
pros: Management puts employees first - this spans the spectrum from work/life balance to career growth.  The work at JHU is challenging and fulfilling - we make contributions that positively impact the state of our country and employees are proud to be a part of that.  There is a real team environment and a lot less of the politics than are seen at other companies.  Working for a non-profit is much less stressful than for-profit consulting.
cons: The hiring process is broken so bringing on other good individuals is a frustrating process that takes patience on both ends.  A lot of business process and systems are homegrown and can be difficult to wade through.

review_title: Hopkins is a great place to do graduate work, if you know what kind of research you want to do.
pros: The faculty and research facilities at Johns Hopkins are top notch. Likewise, Hopkins has a great name around the world, which definitely helps when trying to advance your career and get a post-doctoral position at a new institute. The various departments at the medical school vary in their competitiveness, but if you are accepted into a top-notch department then you will be surrounded by a great set of colleagues.
cons:
Unfortunately, the mentorship of graduate students isn't a strong focus from a management perspective, and a lot of students are left to fend for themselves.

Low pay, which is to be expected as a graduate student. The health benefits vary widely depending on the department you belong to.

job_title: Senior Development Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: Abundance of training opportunities, potential for growth, highly regarded in the industry, great benefits, wonderful employees.
cons: Low salary, growth takes longer than it should and is more about who you know, minimal to no telecommuting allowed despite what the HR website says, VERY heirarichal environment and admin staff are not valued and are given lip service, dismissive of previous experience unless it precisely matches the job description, not a very accommodating environment for women who have families (most of the development employees are women of childbearing age and once they have children, most end up quitting, except those in higher-level positions), coordinators  have to be technical experts with extensive knowledge of varying systems but are undervalued, they are all about titles.

pros: Most of the junior staffers were very pleasant people to work with.
cons: The challenge was not the content of the work. The organization is essentially an event organizing institution for the Korean government. The work is typical boring think tank work that does not translate beyond the walls of the office and has no implication on the real world. The real challenge is working with the higher level staff, who don't acknowledge or appreciate junior staffers. There is a lot of favoritism in play. Multiple staffers, including myself, have been discouraged by management to pursue a career path because of our gender (being women). Overall just a bad place to work and progress. Wouldn't recommend it to anyone looking to pursue a career in international affairs.

review_title: Good starter, but move on before it's too late
pros: You can learn a lot from some of the brightest minds in the world just by chatting them up in the hallway. Really fantastic health and dental (if you don't do EHP - BCBS is super portable) And free access to just about every journal article ever and having people being impressed when you name drop where you work are nice perks, too.
cons:
If you don't have at least a Master's, don't expect to see much advancement. The pay bites, too - a 1.5% cap on yearly performance-based raises means you're making less real money year after year, thanks to inflation. 

Also, egos abound, petty politics sucks, and effective communication skills are heavily lacking.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Baltimore, MD
pros: There are so many opportunites at Hopkins to help you to succeed in a career as a research scientist.  If you take an active approach and take advantage of these opportunities you can become 1st author on multiple publications, present or attend numerous seminars, join postdoc associations, take classes and of course have working at the world famous Johns Hopkins on your CV.
cons: Unfortunately, your success as a postdoctoral fellow depend on whether your mentor takes an active part of your research or if your mentor spends anytime in lab.  My mentor was an MD and spent a lot of his time with patients.  I barely saw him once a month and had to do a lot of things myself.  Also, Hopkins, like any other place, is shortage of funding.  If you work here, just be weary of that.

review_title: APL was once a great place to work... no more.
job_title: Assistant Branch Supervisor in Laurel, MD
pros: There are some opportunities to work on revolutionary projects in a variety of areas.
cons: Management has lost focus on the mission and vision, while attempting to build modern looking facilities and increase fee for the parent university.  When the staff size cap was removed, APL stopped being selective about work that it accepted due to the need to maintain large numbers of staff.  The steady influx of new staff has destroyed the culture, loyalty, and in many ways, the professionalism of the lab.  This is happening in an environment where unqualified people are being accelerated into line management positions before they are ready or experienced for all the wrong reasons.  The overall organizational focus on technical excellence has been lost in recent years.

pros:
1. Wonderful and friendly work environment
2. Everything I need in terms of hardware and software necessary for my job has always been taken care of (All my computers and systems have always been upgraded to the latest specifications). Being a software engineer that really makes a huge difference as work becomes faster and efficient with latest technology
3. A lot of encouragement is given for professional certifications and other job related exams. Everything needed from books to exam fees is taken care of. Also, an individual gets a bonus when he/she passes the exam successfully (This is surely a motivation )
4. Work from home is allowed for certain days.
cons: The only con I see is that most of the people are less satisfied in terms of Salary and Benefits.

review_title: Challenging environment.  Lots of talent.  Known for academics and research, not business processes
pros: Working with some brilliant people can be motivating.  You won't become rich working at Hopkins, but you can make a living.  Lots of opportunity for training and advancement.  Good work is recognized.
cons: You may have to move laterally to move up.  Talent is in the Academic and Research areas.  Business leadership tends toward bureaucratic.  You won't hear "thank you" from the top very often, but collegial relationships can be developed to accomplish what needs to be done.

review_title: Get mugged on the way to work?  The "Hopkins Way" isn't working with present day professionals.
pros: Able to work with a lot of interesting people with a variety of interests
cons: The actual working environment leaves a lot to desire.  There are 1/2 hour walks to your meetings through some rough neighborhoods - odds are that you'll get mugged on the way to a meeting or just going to work in the morning.  The security guards there hit on students and are not very effective.

review_title: The leadership is lacking and unwilling to collaborate or acknowledge there betters.
pros: You are in a very collaborative environment where you can get people to do things for you across departments. You can speak with first rate scientists in other departments.
cons: The Urology Department where I worked there are VERY few good papers coming out. People are very nice, but they are not good researchers. It is no wonder Urology brought Johns Hopkins down to the 3rd best hosipital from number 1.  Also, I was laid off with only 2 months notice when my director knew my appointment would not be extended 1 year ahead of time.

pros:
Very energetic, productive, prestigious faculty 
Lots of opportunity and freedom to develop a research agenda
Excellent library and research support staff
Excellent, intellectually focused students
Senior faculty are welcoming and generous when asked
Baltimore is interesting with decent cost of living and rich local culture
Close to DC and NYC
JHU is an urban university with multiple campuses in Baltimore and DC. University leadership is taking positive steps to improve neighborhoods around its various campuses
Lots of opportunities for non-faculty spouses
cons:
Very little mentoring
Senior faculty do not take initiative in reaching out to new faculty
Very high pressure "publish or perish" culture
Baltimore's reputation as a high crime city is way overblown. Lots of local news focusing on crime, but actual statistics are not so bad. The city is quickly gentrifying with many safe, affordable neighborhoods.

review_title: Try to get your own funding before coming here. If not, go elsewhere.
pros: Exceptional Facilities. Brightest researchers and clinicians, Well-funded from the Federal Government
cons: Postdoctoral training here is unsatisfactory and way behind other schools of similar standing. Although postdocs here are offered diverse options to expand their transferable skills, many are either not allowed to participate or are too afraid to even ask if they can participate. Although Hopkins is known for their exceptional faculty, many of them are leaving for better pay, a more collaborative environment, and greater respect from leadership. Entrepreneurship here should be stronger.

pros: Great benefits package, but salaries are far too low to retain competent staff, at least in IT. The work environment is pleasant, and there are some good people to work with, and the campus environment is nice.
cons: Senior management seem more interested in vendor kickbacks than maintaining reliable infrastructure or, god forbid, innovate. The Peter Principle is definitely at work here, and it shows. I once considered sending a fruit basket or flowers to a co-worker just because I was so delighted someone was actually competent at their job. Then I realized how crazy it is to be amazed by such an occurrence.

job_title: Senior Research Specilislist/Lab Manager in Edgewood, MD
pros: Great benefits at the Senior Staff level, pay is comparable to other academic employers in the area.  Up until this lab, I have never had a problem settling in right away.
cons: I've never had a lab at Hopkins let me go before, and never have I been let go inside the 90-day probationary period, but this lab did so, stating that I was not learning the job quickly enough for their satisfaction.  5 weeks is an awful short time to learn everything they were throwing at me, especially when the woman teaching me the most difficult aspect of the job, had zero teaching skills, and had only learned the procedure herself 2 months prior.

pros: First of all the vast majority of employees at Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Lab were in the top 10% of their class.  One of the best things about working here is that you never stop learning.  There are a huge variety of things to choose from and almost anyone with a background in science can find something here that they love to do.  The retirement package is amazing.  (2.5% + match x2).  Flex time is amazing, especially for those non-morning people.
cons: Academic affliation can be prohibitive to some government contracts.  It seems like we aren't able to pull in some of the really cool work.

pros: Working for Johns Hopkins University on campus allows you to meet all types of people and broaden your horizon. You will constantly be filled with all types of great resources and knowledge including employee resources. I've had the privilege of working with some exceptional people.
cons: The company does not do well with raises. Also, the company has a difficult process when it comes to firing someone. However, they have NO problem laying you off suddenly without warning. This company is selfish and cut throat at times. Be-careful when working for them and the health insurance is not beneficial to employees.

job_title: Associate Professional Staff II in Laurel, MD
pros: Excellent technical work and a great benefits package. Working for this company earns you an instant credibility with others in the business. It is an excellent bridge between government and industry, and allows one to serve as an honest broker for the government and taxpayer on some of the most important technical projects going on in the country.
cons: The pay scale is extremely secretive and career growth is often slow to happen. Time in service is often favored over what you put into the job.

review_title: Great for the resume but not a long term stop
job_title: Carey Business School in Baltimore, MD
pros: The benefits are awesome and the work is dirt easy, the pace is super slow though sometimes it is too slow.
cons: They pretty much don't give raises, at Carey I've gotten stellar annual reviews and been awarded 1.25% and 1.4% salary increases. It's just not sustainable long-term.  Even worse they act like they're really hooking you up by giving you over the school average of 1%.

review_title: Solely depends on faculty and department
pros:
Pay is really good for how few hours you can work and even the worst professor I worked for was looking out for my courseload.

If you work for someone good, you get a fantastic letter of rec and solid experience in teaching, organization, and leadership.
cons: If you work for someone bad, they can fail to turn in a letter of rec on time, rarely show up to their own class, and falsify your pay structure.  Seriously, there's minimal oversight, so if your professor is great, it's great, if your professor is awful, it's awful.

pros: Has great professors and resources; good for sharpen expertise and expand network; students are very bright, makes the teaching very joyful;
cons: neighborhood is not very safe; postdoc health insurance is bad, especially if you have family; homewood and medical campus are far from each other, not easy if you need to work at both places; staffs are disorganized and very slow, it took my colleague 1 year to get reimbursement, and took me and my advisor 1 month to find out who is in charge of the renewal of my appointment

review_title: Everyone thinking on contributing to the science and work hard towards that, which is exactly what I wanted.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Baltimore, MD
pros: Networking, opportunities for professional growth within the same university or health system, students are also amazing. Health benefits are fair and the city has those key spots that makes you love the city once you get used to it.
cons: Long work hours and abundant pressure to deliver high quality results. I also do not like the food on campus.

review_title: Benefits & Hours Great, Salary Could be Better
job_title: Academic Program Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: The hours are great, the benefits are great, and having the name Johns Hopkins on a resume is also great!
cons: Salaries could be higher. Parking has to be paid for ($120 per month), for a garage that is nowhere near capacity. If the parking were less expensive that would be great, but coupled with low salaries, it feels like having a car is a burden.

review_title: Hopkins is a great place to work
pros:
Salary is in line with the NIH recommendations as expected. 

Excellent health insurance. It is free for an individual, but will cost about $700 monthly for a family.  However, the coverage is really quite good.  They recently added IVF. 

Really good support for postdoctoral fellows.  They are really focused on making sure that postdocs move on to a career that is not necessarily academia.  There are many workshops, meet and greet sessions and the like throughout the year.  They also offer one-on-one career counseling.
cons: Aside from the cons that come with being a postdoc in general, there are not too many to working at Hopkins.  It really depends on your mentor.

pros: Nothing positive. If you have college kids you could get a discount on their college education.  That was the only pro I can think of. Just glad I got out of there.
cons:
Terrible manager who was in experienced and did not know how to manage. Hired me even though I told him repeatedly that I did not have database experience. He said it was fine I would learn it.  3 months later yells at me for not having database experience.  
Worked nearly 60 hours a week with no recognition of my efforts.  Was falsely told of "great benefits" when I paid through the nose for the health insurance. How is that great benefits? I was under paid due to the "Hopkins name" thats great if i were a physician?

pros: outstanding work environment with many stimulating intellectual opportunities
cons: salary is tied to how much grant money you bring in // space, students, etc are all dependent on continued NIH funding // consider a position only if you've ability to bring in outside money for 20-30 years, otherwise, startup time will be good, but long-term less so // administration support is largely focused on those currently bringing in federal-dollars

review_title: Clinical Customer Service rep- love who I work with, don't like who I work for
job_title: Clinical Customer Service Representative in Baltimore, MD
pros:
-the name/reputation of course
-amaaazing benefits..health/dental/pharm coverage pays for so much
-a lot of opportunities to stay in the company and move around since Hopkins' name is everywhere (ie Bayview, JHU, Suburban, JH Community Physicians etc..)
cons:
-staff is treated horribly, especially the nurses. Mostly its the scheduling/staffing of the floor. Too many patients per nurse= patient care goes down= patient conditions deteriorate
-the budget is cut down to the bare bones, causing staff shortages (see above)

pros:
City employment is safe if you stay on the grid.

Leadership and co-workers are intelligent, socially aware, and correct in terms of HR.

A positive experience on the whole, considering training and value of work.
cons:
Office systems are technically challenged and less advanced that outlying areas.

Commute and parking are problematic in that city center is jammed by ceaseless road repair and an increased number of office buildings. Baltimore inner harbor is now overpopulated and needs redesign.

JH staff includes some folks beyond retirement age who resist social and technical advances of the 21st century.

Job title for RESEARCH means Advanced degree or higher, thus half JH jobs are never filled.

pros: Amazing experience to interface with internationally recognized research leaders, good access to wide variety of technologies and multidisciplinary expertise. For PhD researchers, JHMI was one of the first (and might still be one of the few) places where MDs and PhDs work side by side, learn from each other and bring a team approach to solving complex clinical and biological problems. Truly bench to bedside type translational research.
cons: Exhausting work hours, work overload, poor technical support, salaries are known to be 30% below market. Some facilities are run down and need infrastructure upgrade. Neighborhood is sketchy but you get used to it quickly. Bureacracy is about average for a large academic medical institution.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Few distractions.   Very comprehensive university services, especially library service and gym.   Most colleagues have very high academic standings.
cons: Very small campus consists of small departments.  A lot of research directions are simply absent.   Few recreational (other than the gym) options.   No good restaurants nearby and the security situation deteriorates only 2 blocks from campus.    To put it simple:  lots of work but no life.

review_title: Great mission, but relies on the name
pros: A terrific place to kick off my career. Good teamwork, lovely campus, great mission that is easy to believe in. Hours are nice, and you frequently interact with some brilliant thinkers.
cons: Hopkins seems to rely on the "Hopkins name" factor, that is, it's so well known in Baltimore that working there should be enough for talent. But the pay/benefits are not competitive, and not even consistent between departments. It's a great place to start your career, but unless you want to stay in academia, you should begin looking elsewhere after a good couple years of experience and growth.

review_title: Great outlook for future job opportunities
pros: Great outlook for future job opportunities.  You get to work with some of the brightest people and help impact lives tremendously
cons: Bad work/life balance, with very low wages.  Even when comparing the University to its competitors they underpay their workers. There is an expectation that because you get the opportunity to help people and work at such a great university, you will be willing to work long hours with very little pay.

review_title: Use it as a stepping stone.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: prestige. It will help you get where you want to go.
cons: Baltimore is not the nicest city in the world. And that, of course, is an understatement.Crime rates are high, The majority of neighborhoods are dangerous. There is not a lot, aside from Hopkins, that would have ever brought me to Baltimore. Now that my time is up here, I am thrilled to be leaving this "city"My recommendation: Work in Baltimore, but live in Towson. There has been a great deal of expansion and gentrification of the neighboring communities. However, the medical campus, and surrounding areas are still rough/.

pros: Tuition remission, reputation, great president! Great research and hospital. Many highly intelligent people to learn lots from. Work life Balance. Many opportunities to engage the community and give back. Lots of training.
cons: Very decentralized environment so it can be difficult to build relationships. Silo driven in many ways. Difficult to get answers to solving questions so you can often be left to making your own decisions. Sometimes a good thing; sometimes not so much. Can be difficult to be promoted. Some of the professional development courses are not that great which is disappointing!

pros:
Does good work
Pays pretty well if you start with a good salary
Connected to Johns Hopkins University (prestige)
cons:
Bad management from the top
No opportunities for career growth, no mentoring, not much room for growth.
No consistency. CCP is ok if you're on a good team with a smart manager, but everything varies team to team. There are no center-wide policies. 
Horrible atmosphere. Some senior staff bully other members of staff. HR is useless. Bad communication. A lot of passive-aggressive people.
Very clique-y. If you're not a member of the leadership clique, it's a hard place to work.

review_title: JHU APL is a great place to work if you value job flexibility, low stress atmosphere, reasonable pay and job stability.
pros:
The best reasons to work at APL are as follows:
1) The job flexibility is unmatched, very flexible with time off, vacations, hours worked (some people come in at 6am, some at 11am, some flex-time, etc).
2) The people I work with at APL are very smart, capable, and helpful.
3) Opportunity for paid education, they will pay for your Masters, MBA, PhD as long as you work here.
4) Work on very interesting projects.  Flexibility of which projects you get to work on.
cons: Some under performing staff are not let go.

pros:
- Benefits
- Flexible Hours
- Stable

With steady flux of money from NIH, NSF the paycheck is assured. I never heard anybody ever getting fired.
cons:
- Salary
- Advancement opportunities
- Lack of deadlines (really)
- Management

Millions of dollars are going down the drain because the for ex. the CIO is totally absent. I can't even say "incompetent" as I never saw any trace of presence.
Also the Patent office is changing leadership every year, at least. Virtually no patent is hitting the market. Too bad.

So if you want a steady job, work whenever you wish (or not), low end salary is OK - this is your dream company.

review_title: JHU has a lot of TA vacancies every semester.
pros: Being an TA at Johns Hopkins University  is not so hard and if you perform well, in most cases, you will be asked to be the TA for the next semester too. Hence TA is a good income resource for full time students, especially for international students who are not allowed to work outside campus during the semesters.
cons: The hourly pay of TA is low while compared with the research assistant. However, some times professors may ask TA to do some research work that usually should be assigned to a research assistant (in this case, the professor may do not have a research assistant).

review_title: Great employer, generous benefits and PTO, employee centered work-life balance culture depending on department
pros:
The organization culture and structure empowers managers and supervisor who are employee centered to develop and promote a positive work-life balance. 
Benefits are above overall market standards
Pay is relatively competitive
cons:
Tuition reimbursement benefits lagging behind other institutions in the Washington D.C market
Lack of strong culture and structure to retain highly qualified home grown employers. Qualified and growth oriented employees come to look at institution as a stepping stone to better opportunities

job_title: Senior Research Specialist in Baltimore, MD
pros: A diverse work environment.  Education benefit is the real benefit here.
cons: JHU administration does not support research employees and do not have any sort of retention plan in place when funding for positions is tight.  Do not let the door hit you on the way out.  Even senior staff are not valued.

pros: The environment is a nice mix of academic and industrial; we get to do innovative new thinking and apply it to the real world.  It is an unusually egalitarian culture.  Technical staff have a large degree of autonomy in selecting what they work on.
cons: Individual staff members bear significant responsibility for bringing in new grants and contracts.  You can work on whatever you want, but you have to find the money for it.  Lack of graduate students (for cheap labor) sometimes hampers our competitiveness.

job_title: Recreation Center Monitor in Baltimore, MD
pros: Johns Hopkins University is full of great people in a supportive atmosphere.  A lot is expected of you, but they have every right to demand the best support for their students.
cons: I can't really think of any cons that would apply to the entire university.  I worked part-time at the Recreation Center as a Monitor, which was rather boring and repetitive, but you can't really expect more from a job the main requirement of which is to watch students and university affiliates and make sure they don't hurt themselves or the facility.

review_title: Great reputation, some of the bureaucracy can be frustrating
pros: Great benefits, including 403b contribution and ample vacation/sick time.  Great name recognition with the job.  Good opportunities to conduct a wide variety of research. Great people who are really passionate about their work.
cons: Very hierarchical as expected in an academic institution.  Bureaucracy would get in the way of innovation/creativity sometimes.  Some departments have a better work-life balance than others.  In some, it seems that working on the weekends and at night is required.  In a soft funding environment this may be expected given the current nature of research funding.

pros:
Benefits:  JHU offers great leave, vacation, retirement, & tuition plans.
Prestige:  The Hopkins name goes a long way when you look for your next job.
cons:
The salaries are lower than what you would make in "industry".

Be careful if you work over on the medical campus! There is some theft and robberies and people get hit by cars if they don't pay attention crossing the street. Stay alert and don't play with your phone when walking around.

It's a HUGE system, so sometimes it seems like you get lost in the shuffle or that departments don't communicate with each other. I generally work with HR/payroll staff in my department if I have that sort of issue.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Good pay for work - we are well-compensated for the work that we put in.
cons: No guarantee of continued employment - although I am one of the most experienced undergraduate TAs in Chemistry (I have TA'd four classes), I am not guaranteed continued employment as a TA because graduate students (who never actually took the course they are TAing; I have taken the course) receive priority over undergraduates.

review_title: High Turnover, Terrible Management, No Retention Efforts
job_title: Assistant Director of Development in Baltimore, MD
pros: tuition remission after 1 year of service. great budget for supplies, professional development, work space. If you have children, tuition reimbursement for children after 2 years of service. Good brand/name recognition in higher-ed field nationwide.
cons: Upper management leaves on average after 2 years and is only interested in their own professional development. Department Heads are not hired to manage and grow their team; most prefer to focus only on their own metrics established by the dean. Across the university, leadership does not invest in retaining their staff.

pros: You can review some of the knowledge while doing TA.  Only 10 hours per week. It is quite helpful for a student to be a TA. You can also get some money while you are studying there.
cons: It may be easier for PHD student to get the position. For undergraduate and master student, you just apply as soon as possible.

job_title: Senior Program Officer in Baltimore, MD
pros: Fantastic people at all levels that know how to work hard but have fun. If you are good, you can move ahead quickly. Opportunities to get involved in all different parts of the organization if you are willing and enthusiastic. Great travel opportunities and a real commitment to its staff. Salaries are pretty good and excellent benefits - including generous 403b plan and vacation time. Don't agree with comments here about it being passive aggressive - I have never found that.
cons: being affiliated with the university has its benefits but it makes the processes to get things done slow and cumbersome.

pros: Time off benefits were tremendous along with 403b match.   Lots of the best and brightest minds in one place.  Plenty of opportunity to move laterally.  Pretty flexible with time.  Decentralized - no micromanaging.
cons: Baltimore - not a great place to live and if you drive in you pay to park and commute.  Upper management never changes - people or viewpoints.   No training given to PhD/MD division directors as managers, that impacts everyone under them.

pros: Independence, great mentors, and a plethora of experts to learn from.  Management seems to be quite hands off and only requires periodic reviews as long as results are good.  The benefits are amazing and the name recognition from Johns Hopkins doesn't hurt either.  For someone who is older and retired military, the opportunities here are seemingly endless.
cons: Academic attitudes....lots of smart people means lots of opinionated people.  Some people rest on their "laurels" (no pun) and ride the Hopkins name in external meetings with no facts to support their position.    More competition than one would think, coming to an academic environment.

review_title: JHU/APL - a great place for the technically oriented.
job_title: Deputy Program Manager in Laurel, MD
pros: Quality personnel, quality tasks, great environment.  These comments relate to the Applied Physics Laboratory, since the system wouldn't let me cull it out.
cons: There's an academic reluctance to reward excellence, and a similar lack of backbone to hammer the non-performers.  Luckily most folks are fantastic and this isn't a huge problem.  There is also a reluctance to break out of the traditional focus areas and engage in new, possibly more challenging tasks.

pros: The university has extensive resources from an academic point of view. Funding is not as big of an issue like some other top US universities especially if you are conducting medical research.
cons: A PhD takes longer than usual for a variety of reasons. Professors are in the habit of holding onto their grad students since they want them to publish more and they do not (usually) need to worry about funding. The academic institutions do not do a good job of integrating with the industry. It is a great place to be if you love to do science, but perhaps you should look elsewhere if you seek more practicalatity.

pros: Having been staff at three universities I'd say JHU is the best run of all of them.  It's still higher ed and very decentralized, but given that they do a very good job.
cons: JHU seems kind of stodgy for higher ed -- some of the informality that's usually a benefit of this industry (and that I appreciated elsewhere) is missing here.  Also, making a career path without switching jobs (even inside JHU) can be tough due to how the job bands are defined.

review_title: You're better off at University of MD
pros:
-Good educational benefits
-Homewood campus is nice
-Work/life balance is pretty good (depending on where you work)
-Generous vacation/sick leave
cons:
Had such high hopes in coming to work at Hopkins, it's been so disappointing.  Many of the managers tend to micromanage and do not develop their staff.  Lack of career growth opportunities.  Have seen some really questionable behavior from leaders, there's a lack of integrity and accountability.

-JHU pays at the low end, you can find the same job at University of MD for higher salary
-Managers don't know how to manage, but think they do
-Deans can derail someone's career if they don't like them
-Very siloed
-Takes FOREVER to make a decision
-Have to pay for parking
-No bonuses

job_title: Senior Research Project Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: The JHSPH is the leading public health institution, and there are excellent research studies that are conducted throughout its various departments. There is also lots of collaboration with the other JHU schools (Medicine & Nursing). The benefits are OK.
cons: The salary isn't as high as non-academic settings, and the location of the school (it's surrounded by bad neighborhoods) isn't appealing. As long as you park on campus it is OK. Food options for lunch are very limited.

review_title: Little job security for research scientists
pros: Good infra-structure and office management support. There are bright people, but little support for young scientists. You are on your own, and need to go somewhere else if you want a permanent position.
cons: No job security since many research positions are based on research grants. This could be different in medical school campus where some money comes from clinical revenue.

pros: Supportive, experienced management. While working here, it was evident that all administrators and managers knew what to do in the event of change or the unexpected.
cons: The cafeteria food is lackluster, and frequently repetitive -- look forward to the same breakfast, every day. And they don't even have grits!

pros: I can work with friends; I can work at home; it is kind of chill; I can tutor and help other students who would admire and be thankful to me. What more can I say?
