cons: Grading homework can get a lot of time sometimes you know. It is pretty annoying if a student writes some complicated and long and unclear, you know bro? I don't even want to talk about it.

pros: The job is pretty flexible. You can generally choose what shifts you'd like and when you want to work. Also, its a great way opportunity for high school and college students
cons: The management can be kind of rude and condescending at times. The pay is not great either and there really are no pay increases on the job. The parents of the students can also be quite rude at times.

review_title: Advanced Academic Programs is a VERY Troubled Department
pros: Flexible work schedule, great health benefits, tuition remission, generous dependent child tuition benefit, access to Johns Hopkins classes and degree programs
cons:
Decentralized (but still bureaucratic), low salaries compared to private industry, lack of transparency in management decisions, growing focus on the bottom line over quality education and research, high turnover, no raises. 

The department (Advanced Academic Programs) experienced a sudden leadership transition -- its dean unexpectedly resigned and was promptly replaced the next day. There was no information about how the replacement was selected.

When it was determined that faculty and staff had discovered negative stories about the new dean on her previous employer's student newspaper website, that site was briefly blocked at AAP (and then restored). 

Although the department brought in a great deal of revenue, huge cuts were instituted because that revenue did not meet the parent school's projections. The parent school (Krieger School of Arts and Sciences) employees were granted a cost of living increase, but Advanced Academic Program's employees were not, despite also being employees of the parent school. AAP staff were told that this was because of our "poor performance," although the department still brought in more revenue to the parent school than all of the traditional academic departments.

Longtime faculty resigned, the department's only HR manager was reassigned to the main campus (and then resigned), a senior administrative manager left for another school at Hopkins and every member of the marketing department and web team left AAP voluntarily in the course of several months and were replaced by temps. Full-time replacements were not hired. Rumors of job cuts abounded, and several employees were demoted or lost their jobs. Staff members who left have not been replaced -- and budget cuts have severely limited several academic programs (in some cases, the cuts made it so that only a handful of courses could be taught per semester). 

Faculty and staff have been reprimanded for informing students about the budget cuts and departures and there was a department-wide edict that students are not to be told when senior faculty or staff leave the program.

review_title: A dead end Admin job that barely got my foot in the door, laid off after restructuring.
pros: Decent benefits - at least in a climate wear benefits are getting pretty pitiful. Some great people to work with. I've heard that other people have had better work environments and opportunities, so I guess its the luck of the draw in what school/department you are hired into.
cons: Some really unfortunate changes in management. Relatively frequent "Job Abolishment" streaks. A lack of commitment to support staff.

pros: Hub of science, great opportunity to learn, interact with the best people in the field, multidisciplinary collaborations. Great recreation center with classes to promote well-being.
cons: Unhealthy work-life balance, not family friendly, no day care facility for mothers. High crime rate in the area - even close to campus is not very safe. Health benefits do not cover a lot of things. Need better mental health care facilities. Food options on campus are not great.

pros:
Salary is great, and the people I work with are smart and interesting.

The university as a whole has a boatload of money, which is often spent frivolously but does create some amazing opportunities for staffers.
cons:
I find the vibe is very "corporate," meaning lots of bland group-think and empty jargon without enough deep thinking or critical assessment. Most people are just riding comfortably on their cushy jobs with high salaries and great benefits. There's an air of complacency.

As a part-timer I unfortunately don't  have access to those benefits, which is a tough pill to swallow.

pros: Regular 8.30a - 5p shift and Rarely required to stay later than 5p
cons: Toxic environment: coworkers are moody, Low salary offers: Hopkins is not at all competitive in the field of cytogenetics, Management: says they have an open door policy but if you have questions they are met with irritation and a condescending attitude; Manager and Lab supervisor choose favorites in the lab

job_title: Academic Program Manager in Baltimore, MD
pros: Cosmopolitan culture, an environment where people are actually doing great things to help people. Some good benefits , such as decent health and some tuition support for continuing ed.
cons: JHU not know for paying well, and the JHU system overall is siloed.   I think this is less true of Public Health than some other divisions of JHU, though.  Concern for future of PH if NIH funding is severely cut.

review_title: Look elsewhere if you want a career in clinical research
job_title: Research Program Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros:
- Benefits - The benefits package as a whole is great, though the health insurance is more costly (and carries higher deductibles and out of pocket maximums) than those of other universities in the area.
- PTO -- Employees start at 2 weeks.  After 1 year, you get 15 days.  After 7 years it jumps to 22 days.  Senior employees automatically receive 22 days, I believe.
- Sick time - 12 days per year is well above the standard
- Hopkins pays for long-term disability.  
- 403(b) Vesting – Once eligible (a con below), JHU’s contribution is fully vested and placed automatically into an account, regardless of whether or not the employee contributes. 
- The "Name" -- having Hopkins on your resume never hurt anyone
cons:
- JHU grossly underpays its employees across the board -- my current salary is in the 6th percentile when compared to individuals at other institutions with comparable educations and years of experience.  Management claims there is just “not enough money” to give their employees a fair, competitive wage.
- JHU offers a job, not a career -- promotions are hard to come by, even for outstanding work.  My colleagues and I were told that "HR" has made it "more difficult to promote" in recent years.
- Retirement benefits unfairly treat those under 35, who arguably would benefit most from employer contributions given the additional years that money could compound.  You have to be over 35 or an employee of Hopkins for at least 2 years to receive the employer "match". Hopkins also does not offer a Roth 403(b).
- Pressure from senior leadership to open more clinical trials than the cancer center can manage. This "quantity over quality" approach leads to serious errors, employee burnout and high turnover.
- Absent PIs -- Investigators open all of these trials but are rarely around. Even when they are, they do not have any interest in sitting down with the research team to review AEs and discuss the progress on their trials.  
- Lack of appreciation -- 99% of the clinical trial work is left to the study coordinators, research nurses, and NPs who get little recognition and appreciation. This could come in the form of wages or promotions, but even a simple “Thank you for all of the hard work you do” would suffice.  
- JHU is behind the times in terms of letting employees work from home.  The HR website says work-life balance is important, but at a department level, it’s rare to come by.  In my program, the managers and PIs often do work from home, but it’s not even an option for study coordinators even 80% of our job is spent in front of a computer.

review_title: A solid place to work, though be prepared to do a lot of self-promotion to succeed
pros:
-My boss was always very supportive of me as both a professional and a person
-The job was generally interesting, and I enjoyed some of the challenges I was able to contribute to solving. 
-Coworkers were generally friendly. 
-There are few employers to put on your resume that carry the prestige JHU does. 
-PTO policy was outstanding. 
-Some opportunity to work remotely and flexibility in scheduling
-Employees get near top of the line laptops and other technology, which is the opposite of much of the education world
-Awesome multimedia facilities
-Most faculty are great

I enjoyed working there, though your experience will greatly vary based not only on which school you work for, but which department you are in.
cons:
-Health insurance premiums and copays are expensive compared to other higher education employers, even those in the private, for-profit sector. 
-Tuition reimbursement/remission at the graduate level pales in comparison to most universities. 
-There is much favoritism disseminating from the vice dean level and above 
-Success is tied to how much you talk about yourself and look busy, whilst more reserved folks carrying heavy workloads are overlooked. 
-Endless meetings, most of which didn't accomplish much (you need to clearly define who has decision-making authority and stay on task). This meant longer hours and working in the evenings and on weekends to catch up. 
-There are a lot of politics, particularly when you are staff- faculty will ALWAYS be in the right, no matter how abusive they choose to be. This trend is common in academia, but not to the extent that I witnessed and personally experienced at JHU.  This only applied to a select minority of faculty, but the fact that it happened regularly without repercussion isn't ok.

review_title: A great place to be from, but not a great place to be
pros: The benefits are good.  The amount of health insurance, dental and vision options is great, plus they give you a stipend to buy these options.
cons: Hopkins is set on underpaying its hardest workers just because they are Hopkins.  The management is terrible.  There is no security as everything depends on grants and PIs often overspend, leading to constant layoffs.  Hopkins is a great place to be from, but not a great place to be.

pros: Excellent environment, intellectually stimulating work. Fantastic peers and mentors. Also, a great degree of freedom when it comes to designing experiments and creating new proposals. Funding is not a concern for most cases.
cons: Food options are somewhat limited to the Charles Village area but there are some good options elsewhere. The amount of effort you put in is what you get in terms of results. No structure is both good and bad depending on who you are.

pros: Access to some of the best researchers and technologies in the region. Lots of resources to grow personally and professionally.
cons: Students and employees on the "lower rung" of academia tend to bear the brunt of any recessions within labs (ie funding). Institution does not go much above and beyond whats required of supporting a graduate student (like most). Easy to get lost or forgotten depending on your PI.

pros: The work environment was very positive and friendly. My supervisor was very flexible and worked around our schedules. The focus on meeting the needs our clients, the students, was constantly emphasized to ensure we are effectively helping them.
cons: There was no proper task delegation, making the work hard and overwhelming during the admissions season. The administrative building can be hard to navigate, leaving people confused about the office they are looking for and making it hard for the front desk employees to figure out the service they are seeking and then direct them to the correct office.

review_title: JHU is a nice place to work and persue career growth, but they're not competitive with salaries
pros:
*JHU Culture
*Access to education benefits for staff and their college age children
*Discounts available to JHU employees (YMCA, Weight Watchers, Amusement Parks etc)
*Benefits package 
*Excellent worklife program for working parents and for staff (Housebuying incentives, adoption assistance benefit, child care etc)
*Ability to advance to other positions throughout the JHU network. JHU jobs website on any given day has at least 400 jobs opening posted and open to apply for. 
*Living Wage initiative for employees. Custodians average starting salary is about $11 per hour
cons:
* JHU Culture 
*University contribution to 403B program for support staff is 20 cents on the dollars
*Poor training program in place to train employees on SAP (new HR/Payroll/Finance software program) introduced 5 years ago. Training class are available but exisiting employees and new hires aren't encouraged  by the departments they work for to learn how to use SAP. JHU spent millions of dollars to purchase to this software.
*Decentralized organization, which affects how the University operates and how policies are perceived and executed. 
*Salaries for support staff positions are not in line with private employers for the similar jobs.
*New P3 Evaluation System for employees, which is being used by some departments (HR Shared Services) to ensure that employee's never receive more than an average rating for their review. Average reviews equate to less money in your paycheck. New system put into place in July 2011. Departments are required to use this system, but most aren't taking it seriously. 
*Favoritism - Who you know at JHU can help or hurt your career goals at Hopkins. Never burn any bridges because it is high probability that you will run into that person again during your climb up the career ladder.
*Elistist Behavior on the department level regarding your educational background
* Yearly Raises avearge 2% for support staff and Sr Staff and Upper Manager 4%-5%

pros: Good benefits, ok salaries, usually a slight raise every year . They offer a lot of training to their staff and encourage people to take classes.
cons: Many of the senior admins are bitter and cynical; hard to fire people who need to be fired; a lot of pushback from people who have been there for 15+ years against implementing new or better systems; most of the senior faculty/ staff/ leadership have an "old boys club" attitude.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Environment is extremely collaborative and there is frequent exchange of resources and ideas between research labs. There is a constant stream of high quality seminars and talks. The research infrastructure is amazing in terms of instruments, facilities and training available to students and faculty. It's really a lively and intellectually stimulating place to be as a biomedical researcher at the East Baltimore campus.
cons:
1. Crime is somewhat high in the surrounding area in East Baltimore. You need to be constantly aware of your surroundings. However, local people do have an unexpected humility and kindness that I have not encountered elsewhere. Local residents never fail to warn me that my lights are not on as I drive away half asleep at 10pm.
2. No current student/postdoc union has yet been formed. Many students complain of exploitation and abuse by their bosses in famous labs but have no recourse. There is a wide range of student experiences in terms of support, mentorship and opportunity to attend outside conferences dependent on individual lab styles. Therefore it is very important for students to choose labs well. The university could put more guidelines in place for faculty conduct.
3. Student "health services" is a joke. Instructors from the School of medicine man the health center and frequently keep textbooks on hand to consult in the event that they forget something. That said, the student health plan is a PPO, so you can go elsewhere.
4. Occupational safety measures/safeguards for students (not considered employees eligible for workers compensation) could be improved. The online safety training is a joke and students are often left scrambling around to find help in the event of fire, flood or burn incidents. That said, there are not that many incidents and they are eventually resolved. The Hopkins emergency room is first rate if you are injured.

pros: Great benefits: up to 44days of vacation and 90days of sick - accumulated annually until you reach max. 12 paid holidays. Tuition remission for self and children. affordable health plans and benefits.
cons: Close to office parking is expensive in garage and is taken out of pay automatically.  offsite parking is cheaper but need to rely on shuttle.  Salary is not as competitive and not very flexible.  Less than average pay for lots of work. You wear multiple hats. Too many political ladders to climb. There are many leaders/managers to answer too and change takes time.

job_title: Academic Program Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: Laid back college campus. Overall nice people throughout. Great health insurance. Good to connect with and learn from great minds.
cons: Kinda like the movie Groundhog Day, things mostly reset and repeat every semester. Unless you have a PhD, your pay will be much less than a similar job outside of the university setting.

review_title: Research Technologist - Johns Hopkins School of Medicine
pros: Johns Hopkins is renowned for being one of the top medical institutions in the country - and for that reason, it looks fantastic on your resume. The people I work with are extremely nice and some of the most intelligent, hard-working people I've ever met.  My schedule is flexible and the environment is fairly laid-back. I can work independently and at my own pace.  It's a great place to work as a jumping-off point for your career.
cons: There are three main complaints I have with working for Hopkins.  The first one is that the East Baltimore campus (which includes the hospital, school of medicine, and other medical facilities) is not a very safe area.  Recently, the've been tearing down vacant houses and expanding the campus, which is good.  However, there are still crimes here all the time.  I get "security alert" emails often notifying me of an assault/robbery that has occurred against a JH affiliate on campus.  My coworker got beaten/robbed recently.  My car has been broken in to multiple times. It is not a safe area to walk around.  And parking is absolutely terrible, which is my second complaint. You either have to pay $120/month for a garage, $70/month for a parking lot several miles away and then take a shuttle to campus or you have to street park - which is what I have done for 5 years and I walk on average a half mile-3/4 of a mile to get to my building.  And walking nearly a mile in a dangerous area is not ideal.  My last complaint is the pay.  Hopkins can get away with paying the absolute minimum to it's employees because of their name.  People will accept low pay to work for the world-renowned "Hopkins!" I make significantly less than people with my same position and experience working at other institutions.  I haven't been promoted in 5 years even though my boss says I'm doing everything above and beyond and has done everything he can to help me get a promotion.

review_title: Good in name, Bad in pay
pros: Great benefits, generous vacation/sick time, many opportunities for growth and research (if that is your interest). The best thing is the name recognition that comes along with the job.
cons: The pay is substantially lower than other companies for staff, not much promotion potential and they tend to hire from outside or offices are very small. Greatest negative is sense of superiority found in many faculty members or other employees.

pros:
a lot of freedom on deciding what to do and how to do
mentor allows you to do what you like
Great for students who don't mind putting in study time, and like to learn a lot. Especially those who are self motivated and driven as well as focused, and enjoy a competitive environment. Also for those who are willing to get involved.
cons:
pure academic environment, no entertainment at all  
The workload can be overwhelming at times
Don't lock yourself in the library 24-7. it is easy to do, but usually only results in incredibly high stress levels

pros: I am currently a MPH student and the research team I work with has made this a wonderful experience for me. I started the job with very little applied experience with research, all I had was what I learned in school. The research coordinator took a chance and gave me the position over a PhD applicant. Great work life balance and being that I am still in school that is very important.
cons: Pay is great for a college student but for a professional with a family and real bills that could be a challenge.

job_title: Senior Associate Director in Baltimore, MD
pros: Able to take advantage of great learning experiences
cons:
I joined the organization hoping that working here would allow me to help support the mission and values.  It's all talk.  
Extremely hierarchical
Slow to make a decision
Career pathing is very limited
Technology for support services is behind the times
No bonus opportunity

President Daniels comes across as pleasant when he's speaking to a large group.  If you're ever in a one on one setting with him he's very dismissive and rude.

pros: Being a teaching assistant was an enlightening experience: you saw how tests were graded and, sometimes, the flexibility that came in grading (maybe this wasn't a fair question; maybe this was worded funny; etc.).  The pay was also pretty good at $12/hr.  And usually professors are understanding come finals time.
cons: No major cons really.  It's a good experience that I would recommend taking if you have the opportunity.  I guess the schedule isn't as flexible as other student jobs because you'll have to be there for class, but that's certainly understandable.

review_title: Great Work Environment but lower on the pay scale
pros: Very supportive environment to work in. Benefits are good but there were substantially cut in the last year I was there.
cons: Constant rumors that senior staff doesn't contribute as much to total benefits as the underlings. The pay is on the low side but You are constantly encouraged to grow professionally and take classes to grow professionally.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Baltimore, MD
pros: If you're a graduate student, you can expect flexible work hours, some opportunities to gain teaching experience,  access to top researchers in your field, and full use of a library with BorrowDirect and Interlibrary loan systems. You'll be well-prepared and qualified for an academic job-- the trouble is that the market in many humanities and social sciences disciplines is terrible.
cons: Low pay not adjusted for inflation. Experience in graduate school depends largely on your adviser.  As is the case for nearly all graduate programs, your adviser has near absolute power over you.

pros:
- Interesting & Large Budget Projects (compared to other universities)
- Training & Certification Opportunities (in-person and online classes)
- Flexible Hours & Paid Time-Off
- Entry-Level Positions with Learning Opportunities
- Work Life Balance
- Friendly Co-Workers
- Philanthropy Opportunities
cons:
- Low Salaries
- Leadership Problems
- Office Politics
- Conflicts between Departments
- Difficulty with Pay & Promotion Increases
- Uneven Distribution of Work & Tasks
- Lack of Business & Online Technology
- Too much focus on quantity versus quality
- Decentralized workplace with duplicate programming and efforts between the different schools, campuses, and departments
- Generation Gap
- Better tuition reimbursement with employment at the state universities

job_title: Systems Engineer in New Freedom, PA
pros: The benefits were decent, lots of vacation and sick time.  Most of the people working there cared about their jobs.
cons: Management was never open with employees.  There was a ladder climbing attitude.  Input to management was never taken seriously.  Pay was low for the position.  Promotion was based more on if the management liked you instead of skills and experience.

review_title: A great place to work as higher ed is involved
pros: Fairly generous salaries for administrative positions in the higher ed sector which tends to be pretty stingy. I loved the office I worked for.
cons: I loved my specific working environment, but higher ed can feel a bit archaic and behind the times with a lot of egos at the top. Also, there's a sense of privilege JHU has in Baltimore and those at the top don't seem to have the best skills to manage it while also helping the community in an honest and open way.

pros: There was an abundance of opportunity to work on global research projects and great opportunities to diversify your own skill set.
cons: There was often a frustrating lack of coordination within research teams that often contributed to inefficiencies in project schedules and budgets. The time and focus of project managers and principal investigators was often spread thin due to the large numbers of project and proposals they pursued.

review_title: Excellent staff and student culture at Lancaster location
pros:
Supportive administration gives instructors the resources they need

Everyone's fairly good at what they do and cares about the mission

Coworkers are fun, intellectual, and good-spirited.
cons:
You get fatigued after three weeks (one session). Six is doable, but you'll feel good when it's over. Do not try to multitask this work with other outside responsibilities.

For people in technical fields, the pay is not very significant relative to what you can get doing an internship.

If you have a choice, pick the Lancaster, PA location.

pros:
Very smart people
Lots of innovative ideas and work
You very much get out of it what you put into it
They pretty much have a job for anything your interested in
cons: Your experience at JHU very much depends on who you report to.  There are many amazing and fantastic managers who make working here a great experience.  There are also lots of not so amazing managers who make peoples lives hell - with those managers it's survival of the fittest.

review_title: A good method to practice English for international student
pros: A good chance to improve my English skill. In addition, it could help me be familiar with your major. The salary is good for student. It could cover the basic expense per month, except the apartment rent. Such experience will be welcome when you looking for a job in the future.
cons: You might face some tough questions asked by students. Also, grading the homework will cost a lot of time. But it is needed. You get pay, you need to work on that.

review_title: World Renowned; Little opportunity for growth.
pros: The reputation of Hopkins is known all over the world.  You have an opprtounity to meet and work with extremely talented people.
cons: Most people at Hopkins know that it is easier to leave Hopkins and then return in the position you than to get promoted within Hopkins. It is an extremely fast paced place to work.

job_title: Human Resources Staff in Baltimore, MD
pros: An  excellent place to progress your education.
cons: Management styles/philosophies/departments are varied.  Due to cuts in spending,  one must do the work of five persons, employee morale at all time low, very top heavy,leadership groups are similar to a secret society, work/life balance is controlled

job_title: PhD Student in San Francisco, CA
pros: Work enjoyment varies from lab to lab. I'm Baltimore the pay is overall pretty good. The campus is really nice also. Makes those longs worth it .
cons: You work many hours. But that comes with the territory.  The begining years are very stressful, but you get used to it. It would be helpful if there was a better way to transition

pros: Student positions at SAIS are very flexible, and supervisors are great at giving the right amount of work for grad students. I have yet to hear someone complain about their position at any department.
cons: HR is one of the worst I have ever encountered- they were constantly missing people's paychecks and paying them at the incorrect rate. If you are going to take a student worker position at SAIS, make sure to follow up with HR in person if they mess up your paycheck and don't stop emailing them until they address the issue- loop in your supervisors as well. Check your pay rate and amount for every check.

pros: Great benefit and great work place.The medical service is top level. The senior employee have the benefit for reimbursing the tuition fee of the kids in college.
cons: Too dull and management need to improve. As many other academic institution, Johns Hopkins University is a private organization, although the efficiency is pretty good but the management in most of the lab is pretty poor.

review_title: Having "JHU" on your resume probably looks good.
pros: Everybody knows the JHU name.
cons: Management does not value input of employees who have professional experience and knowledge.  We are treated as worker bees and the attitude is very much "If you don't like it, leave, there will be a line around the block for your position, and they will do it for much less." It's sort of discouraging.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Baltimore, MD
pros: Some of the most influential methodologists; able to learn most up-to-date statistical and epidemiological techniques.  May have government funding available for PhD level research.  Not difficult to collaborate with the best and brightest.  If you're outgoing and know what you want, you can get a great education here and develop fantastic collaborations.
cons: Strong emphasis on developing academic researchers to the exclusion of breadth of public health education.  Incredibly competitive atmosphere-sometimes hard to reach professors.

review_title: Center for Talented Youth is a surprisingly unprofessional environment
job_title: Residential Program Assistant in Lancaster, PA
pros:
--interesting coworkers from all parts of the educational world
--people go out of their way to help you
--you'll feel like you're in college again
cons:
--interviewer mislead me about what the job would require
--only two days off every three weeks
--hardly allowed to leave campus except on off days
--opening week was was 12-14 hour days for seven days straight, two more similar crunch periods at Intersession and Closing
--cultish work environment in which everyone is overworked but it's unacceptable to say anything
--did not honor my federal tax exemptions, took out far too much in taxes

pros: Office is in a good location
cons: Toxic work environment. Everyone walks egg shells because leadership from main campus sack employees on a regular basis. Work of 10 becomes 5, becomes 2 but they still expect more outcome. Students pay high tuition and don't get the education they are deserve. Dedicated faculty are the only thing that keeps this clock ticking, and the clock is counting down. Irresponsible, short-sighted leadership  interested only in turning a profit, talking students into taking more classes, taking on a larger debt burden. It's sickening.

pros: Johns Hopkins is extremely family oriented and is flexible with work-life issues. The vacation and time-off benefits are very generous. Although salary is on the lower side, the benefits and work-life balance makes up for the difference.
cons: Since Johns Hopkins is a not for profit enterprise, the salary ranges seem to be on the low side. Training budgets are on the low side.
